name: Physics II for Engineering and Physics Students
base_name: Physics II for Engineering and Physics Students
long_desc: This is the second half of a twosemester calculusbased introductory physics sequence for engineering and physics students. Two fifths of the course covers electricity, including electrostatics and electric fields, Gauss law, electric potential, and simple circuits. Two fifths cover magnetism, including magnetic forces, magnetic fields, induction and electromagnetic radiation. One fifth of the course covers mechanical waves including standing and traveling waves, superposition, and beats and electromagnetic waves including mode of propagation, speed, and other properties. This course has a corequisite of 21122.

custom_fields.goals: To learn about the laws of electromagnetism in depth, and the reasoning that led to them, as well as to experience a brief introduction to mechanical waves.
custom_fields.prerequisite_knowledge: Knowledge of mechanics is needed. Knowledge of calculus is required.
custom_fields.assessment_structure: Frequent problem sets, periodic subject examinations, and a final examination
custom_fields.relevance: To learn about the physical theory that underlies our understanding of electromagnetic phenomena and applications
custom_fields.learning_resources: Help sessions are held on Monday, Tuesday, Wednesday, and Thursday evenings
